comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: The Square Dungarvan was redesigned by the Duke of Devonshire in the early 1800's. The richest man in England at the time, the Duke bought up and tore down the warren of small medieval houses in the center of Dungarvan. The resulting Square became the open center of town. =============================================================== And speaking of Dungarvan, I always wondered who Greta Hellstrom was.... Golden haired and golden hearted I would ever have you be, As you were when last we parted Smiling slow and sad at me. Oh! the fighting down of passion! Oh! the century-seeming pain — Parting in this off-hand fashion In Dungarvan in the rain. Slanting eyes of blue, unweeping Stands my Swedish beauty where Gusts of Irish rain are sweeping Round the statue in the square; Corner boys against the walling Watch us furtively in vain, And the Angelus is calling Through Dungarvan in the rain....

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Another angle on that shed, from the nli archive.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: The photographer is high up, possibly at a first-floor window in Parnell Street. View looking north. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,625980,593148,7,9

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A small detail: in this view, the matching windows at the top of the bank and building to the right are both oval. In this Lawrence pic the bank window is arched, and the right hand one oval. In today's streetview, they are both arched.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
Beautiful shot and great detail.  Not only are there two men up ladders but one is a roofer just like the Drogheda ships photo of last week!  You can see the planning that went into the square and the symmetry of the buildings but the Bank has a hell of a lot more chimneys than its opposite number.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] As regards Greta Hellstrom, Wikipaedia has the following - ""The Irish Unionist's Farewell to Greta Hellstrom in 1922" (actually written during the war) which contained the refrain "Dungarvan in the rain". " Greta", the object of his affections, has remained a mystery until recently revealed to have been a member of a well known West Waterford Ascendancy family." but that isn't much help.  Probably like our own Patrick Kavanagh causing a break up of his brothers relationship with Raglan Road he disguised the person to save their blushes???

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: According to the DIA, the National Bank was built in 1859, and remodelled in 1902, so that window doesn't narrow things down at all.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Weak, weary, dejected? Unable to dress yourself? so shrunken you can place an egg in the hollows behind your ears? On the verge of giving up the fight? You need some Mother Seigel's Syrup, available from Messrs Brenan and Co. Grattan Square. You'll soon be walking about strong and hearty, just like Francis Craig of Abbeyside, Dungarvan in 1897. Testimonial for Mother Seigel's Syrup, Lloyd's Weekly Newspaper, Oct30th 1898 After the last 3 months, I think I could do with a bottle or two.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Ha! That's me!  For Brenan see link on note for Post Office.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The 1901 census shows a Francis Craig, aged 62, living with his wife, daughter and 2 sons, in Duckspool, Waterford.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
More Grattan Square trivia:
On August 26th, 1896, Freeman's Journal listed W Cullinane, of Grattan Square, Dungarvan, as winner of the 15th prize in the draw in aid of paying off the debt of the new Star of the Sea Church, Duncannon, Co Wexford. The prize was A Drawingroom Lamp.

[First prize was ' A Gift from His Holiness'
34th (and last) prize was 'a large Doll, dressed as a bride']

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Waterford County Library has several trade directories online, but I can't get figure out how to look in them, pesky newfangled computhers ... www.waterfordcountylibrary.ie/en/familyhistory/tradedirec...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Richard Edward Brenan, who succeeded his father as postmaster, was the winner of the first ever bicycle race in Britain or Ireland in 1869. twitter.com/waterfordmuseum/status/239623798050131970 I don't wish to make any unwarranted accusations, but he did have access so some remarkably effective Performace Enhancing Substances (if Francis Craig is to be believed). Did he win with the help of a hefty swig from a bottle of Mother Seigels's Syrup?
